metadata.title: Medial Epicondyle Apophysitis
synonyms: little league elbow (a broad term used to describe numerous pathologies of the immature elbow)
anatomical location body part affected: The elbow comprises three articulating bones: the humerus superiorly, the radius inferolaterally, and the ulna inferomedially
The medial epicondyle is a bony protrusion on the distal humerus on the medial elbow. The ulnar nerve traverses underneath the medial epicondyle via the cubital tunnel

The medial epicondyle serves as an attachment site for the ulnar collateral ligament and pronator teres and thus is frequently under tension. In a chronologically immature individual, a secondary ossification center develops in the medial epicondyle(1)

An apophysis is a secondary ossification center where a muscle tendon inserts into the bone.(2) In this case, the medial epicondyle apophysis continues to develop until the age of 15 to 17, when it fuses(1,2)

During maturation, the elbow develops five different apophyses:(1) –Capitellum (lateral articular surface of the of the distal humerus) –Radius –Medial epicondyle –Trochlea (medial articular surface of the distal humerus) –Olecranon (proximal prominence of the ulna) –Lateral epicondyle
description: Medial epicondyle apophysitis is an overuse injury of the medial elbow that commonly occurs in young, overhead-throwing  athletes, resulting in a widening of the apophysis and/or fragmentation of the medial epicondyle ossification center(2)

ICD-9 codes.719.42: traction apophysitis of the medial epicondyle

841.base: sprains and strains of elbow and forearm
841.841.8: sprain of other specified sites of elbow and forearm
841.841.9: sprain of unspecified site of elbow and forearm

ICD-10 codes.M92.3: other juvenile osteochondrosis of upper limb (ICD codes are provided for the reader’s reference, not for billing purposes)

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Occurs primarily at 9-14 years of age, during a growth spurt, and observed primarily in baseball pitchers(3)
Presentation may be acute or insidious(4)

The patient may present with the following: –Edema  –Loss of elbow range of motion (ROM)(5) –Pain with palpation along the medial aspect of the elbow, distal arm, and/or proximal forearm(5) –Pain in the medial elbow during throwing(5) –Difficulty maintaining control of the pitch and decreased speed of pitch(5) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: If the patient is presenting through direct access and the condition has not been formally diagnosed by a physician, a referral to a general practitioner or orthopedist is indicated if medial epicondyle apophysitis or other serious pathology is suspected

causes: The secondary ossification center is unable to meet the demands of repetitive valgus forces at the medial epicondyleapophysis, usually with overhead throwing during the cocking and acceleration phases of the pitching motion(1)
Pitching in baseball causes medial traction forces and lateral compressive forces(1)

In older athletes (> 16 years), avulsion fractures of the medial epicondyle and medial collateral ligament are morefrequently due to fusing of the secondary ossification center and increased muscle strength(2)
pathogenesis: Microtrauma caused by the repetitive throwing leads to medial epicondyle apophysitis and may be evidenced on X-ray  bywidening of the apophysis and/or fragmentation(2)

As the bones in children go through different developmental stages, apophyses are susceptible to injury because of theirdecreased ability to withstand tensile forces from strong and repetitive muscle contractions when compared to apophyses ofskeletally mature individuals(6)
The medial epicondyle of the elbow is usually the last ossification center of the elbow to fuse, at about age 15–16(4)
risk factors: Baseball pitchers – risk increases with incorrect technique, training errors, longer competitive seasons (or simply more timepitching), and muscle weakness

The baseball sidearm pitching delivery is associated with a higher risk of elbow injury due to an increased valgus forcewith the whipping motion associated with this type of pitch; three quarters or vertical pitch delivery places less valgusstress on the elbow(7)

As the number of pitches and breaking ball pitches (e.g., curveballs and sliders) increases, the risk for elbow or shoulderpain increases(3)–Based on a prospective cohort study–Four hundred seventy-six  baseball pitchers, aged 9–14  years, were tracked for a season–At least 50% of the participants complained of upper extremity pain during the observation period–Amount of pitches in a game and throughout the season was associated with rate of upper extremity pain–There was an association between-the slider pitch and an increased risk of elbow pain (86% increase in risk)-the curveball and an increased risk of shoulder pain (52% increased risk)
Can also occur in other overhead sports, including tennis and American football(8)
Poor physical conditioning has been associated with medial epicondyle apophysitis(5)
Adolescent males are most commonly affected(4)

overall contraindications precautions: The damaged growth plate may not close if the stressful activity is not discontinued; it is important to educate the patient on the risk of permanent damage if rest period is not adhered to(3,9)
The following conditions can also be present with medial epicondyle apophysitis: Stretching of the ulnar nerve Ulnar collateral ligament sprains(10)

Common elbow injuries in pitchers or the “throwing elbow” include:(11) ulnar collateral ligament tears ulnar neuritis flexor-pronator  muscle strain or tendinopathy  medial epicondyle apophysitis or avulsion valgus extension overload syndrome with olecranon osteophytes olecranon stress fractures osteochondritis dissecans of the capitellum loose bodies
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan

contraindications precautions to examina: If the patient is presenting through direct access and the condition has not been formally diagnosed by a physician, a referral to a general practitioner or orthopedist is indicated if medial epicondyle apophysitis or other serious pathology is suspected

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Clinician should inquire about -symptom onset -patient’s age -hand dominance(5) -sport and position played(5) -intensity of play -number of pitches thrown and type and delivery of pitch (vertical, three quarters, or sidearm)(5) -frequency of pitching(5) -amount of time unable to play sport due to injury

course of treatment.medical management: Ask about patient’s past and current medical management. How has the elbow responded to treatments?
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed; are they being taken?
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests may assist with differential diagnosis
X-ray  may show signs of repetitive stress, injury, or fracture as well as widening of the apophysis and/or fragmentation of epicondyle ossification center
MRI is useful to determine amount of displacement of a fracture, presence of osteochondritis dissecans or loose bodies within the joint(2)
Nerve conduction tests may be ordered to rule out nerve involvement(5)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Aggravating/easing factors  (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased) -Inquire about pain at rest and with activity. Pitching may exacerbate symptoms
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Concurrent Little League elbow and Little League shoulder, also caused by overhead throwing, have been reported(4)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Nature of symptoms -Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -Ask the patient if the joint ever locks (true locking indicates a loose body in joint from a prior injury, osteochondritis dissecans, or severe degenerative changes) -Are there any complaints of numbness or paresthesias?(5)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, if any
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Family history of osteochondrosis? Any history of elbow joint injuries, such as a ligament sprain? Any history of an upper extremity nerve injury? Any history of other sports-related  injuries that could suggest biomechanics or training errors?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient/caregiver about other medical conditions, including diabetes, cancer, cardiac impairments, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc.
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -Has the patient’s position been changed? -Is the patient still participating in the sport on some level?(2) -What is the patient’s current training regimen or warm-up  routine in his or her sport?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Assess current ability to participate in sport or other activities. Patients, parents, and coaches may note a reduction in the velocity of pitches or control over pitches(9)
social and occupational history.living environment: With whom patient lives, caregivers, etc.

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess distal pulses and comparePerform gross neurological screen, paying special attention to the ulnar nerve assessment as irritation of the nerve can be associated with medial epicondyle apophysitis(11) Ergonomics/body mechanics –During pitching, assess balance, body and shoulder rotation, stride length, and follow-through  for a minimum of 5 to 8 pitches at a distance of 33 ft. (10 m) from the side and front views(1)windup, cocking, acceleration, and follow-through -Pitchers tend to rush the windup stage and therefore lose the benefit of using their lower extremities in the kinetic chain. Some authors have argued that the windup stage may be the most important period of the pitching motion because it influences the later stages of the pitching motion(1) -The pitching motion places excessive valgus stress on the medial elbow during the cocking and acceleration stages(1) -The cocking stage begins when the stride foot hits the ground and ends when the shoulder has reached full external rotation(1) -Proposed by authors to be the most studied stage of pitching, the acceleration stage begins when the shoulder has reached full external rotation and ends when the ball leaves the hand(1) -Critical features of proper pitching(1) -Outer portion of the leading hip should point toward the target to assist in proper pelvic/trunk translation and weight transfer -Hand on top of the ball as the ball is taken out of the baseball mitt to promote shoulder internal rotation and forearm pronation  -Elbow at the level or slightly higher than the shoulder during the throwing position to diminish shoulder stress -The leading foot should be pointed towards the target when landing on the ground to promote proper hip/trunk rotation -Avoiding excessive horizontal abduction of the leading shoulder by keeping both shoulders in alignment prior to the acceleration stageAssess medial ligamentous stability by providing valgus stress to the elbow
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Assess upper extremity strength and compare to unaffected extremity -Lateral epicondylitis – pain upon resisted wrist extension and forearm supination(12) -Medial epicondylitis – pain upon resisted wrist flexion and forearm pronation(12) –Be sure to also assess shoulder and scapular musculature
observation inspection palpation includi: Inspect upper extremities and cervical spine; note any areas of atrophy, hypertrophy, or edema
Inspect the elbow for edema or deformity
Evaluate tenderness as pain may be present upon palpation of bony prominences around the elbow, especially the medial epicondyle
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Inspect head, neck, shoulder girdle, and spine for general alignment. Also inspect posture of the spine in sitting and standing positions
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess general ROM throughout, with a specific assessment of elbow flexion, extension, forearm pronation, and supination; compare to noninjured side –Take note that the pitching arm usually has higher external rotation ROM and diminished internal rotation ROM when compared to the non-pitching  arm –If appropriate, assess lower extremity ROM as it pertains to the pitching mechanics
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: The assessment should yield normal results. However, if the ulnar nerve is irritated, the sensory distribution of the ulnar nerve may be affected
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Clinical diagnosis is usually based on complaints of medial elbow pain in a baseball pitcher (in the appropriate age group)(5)

contraindications precautions: Over an area of peripheral vascular disease
Over an area of poor sensation
In the very young or very old

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Pain, edema, loss of ROM, loss of strength, and impaired ability or inability to participate in sport
assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out Fracture Osteoarthritis Rheumatoid arthritis Loose cartilaginous bodies Synovitis Lateral elbow pain(5) –Panner’s disease (avascular necrosis of the capitellum) –Osteochondritis dissecans (see Clinical Review…Osteochondritis Dissecans ; Topic ID Number: T708414) Medial elbow pain(5) –Flexor/pronator strain –Medial collateral ligament/ Ulnar collateral ligament (UCL) injury –Medial epicondyle avulsion –Ulnar neuritis Posterior elbow pain(5) –Olecranon apophysitis –Olecranon impingement –Olecranon osteonecrosis –Triceps avulsion
prognosis: If the injury is recognized and treated in the early stages, there are usually no long-term  consequences
After 12 weeks of rehabilitation and a throwing program, a patient typically returns to competitive pitching/throwing(5)
In most cases, a full return to prior level is obtainable with proper supervision and coaching(4)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Orthopedist – indicated by the presence of(5) –Loose bodies –Avulsion fractures –Osteochondritis dissecans –Lack of response to conservative intervention
treatment summary: In general, care is conservative and begins with rest and activity modification for approximately 2–3 months. Pitchers may be able to continue playing by moving to a different position (such as first base or designated hitter)(2)
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory  drugs (NSAIDs) are generally prescribed; immobilization may be implemented if symptoms are intense(2)

Encourage patients to maintain cardiovascular fitness if unable to play; also encourage stretching and core strengthening . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program  Pain and edema Eliminate pain and edemaActivity modification _ 4–6 weeks of rest (sporting activity ceases or is greatly reduced).(2) For those still pitching, limiting or avoiding breaking balls may be necessary(7) _ _ Physical agents and mechanical modalities _ Ice to decrease pain, inflammation, and edema _ _ Prescription, application of devices and equipment _ Elbow sleeve may be worn for support if needed. Immobilization is used only in severe cases(2)N/A Provide recommendations for home that address pain and edema Decreased ROM Restore normal ROM Therapeutic exercises _ ROM and general upper extremity stretching as indicated. In addition to stretching the forearm and elbow musculature, stretch the posterior shoulder through static glenohumeral internal rotation stretching (e.g., sleeper stretch)(1)Progress each unique patient as indicated and appropriateProvide recommendations for home that address ROM/appropriate stretching  Decreased strength Restore normal strength Therapeutic exercises _ Progressive strengthening of the forearm musculature as well as shoulder and scapular musculature may begin upon resolution of symptoms (approximately 6–8 weeks post injury).(2) Also strengthen the core and trunkProgress each unique patient as indicated and appropriateProvide recommendations for home that address strengthening Inability to participate in pitching/throwing/ sporting activities due to pain or faulty mechanicsFacilitate return to normalized and pain- free pitching/throwing mechanicsWindup stage _ Gradual progression of a throwing program can begin after resolution of symptoms.(5) Instruct pitchers to not rush the windup stage or the benefit of using lower extremities in the kinetic chain will be lost _ _ Acceleration stage _ During the acceleration phase, the body may move ahead of the arm (“opening up too soon”); instruct pitchers to keep the opposite shoulder tucked under the chin so that the arm motion can accelerate prior to trunk rotation _ _ Follow-through stage _ In the follow-through phase, sufficient pelvic rotation will occur by ensuring the stride foot is not placed short of the midline so that the body does not lose momentum. Also see Ergonomics/body mechanics , aboveFull return to sport expected around 12 weeks(5)Provide recommendations to coaches and parents for home management and training concepts that address returning to sport  .

maintenance or prevention: Evaluate throwing mechanics and alter as needed
Enforce proper technique and type of pitching (no curveballs or sliders) in skeletally immature athletes
Preseason conditioning with gradual increase in amount of throwing
Warming up with calisthenics and stretching prior to pitching

The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends limiting the number of pitches to 200 per week with 90 pitches per session. The USA Baseball Medical and Safety Advisory Committee recommends a more conservative approach: 75–125 pitches per week with 50–75  pitches per session. Be sure the athlete includes pitches thrown at home or during physical education class(10)
Adequate rest is needed after injury

Educate players, coaches, and parents on injury prevention,(5) including safe amounts of pitching, adequate rest, and throwing-free  periods.(4) A variety of sports rather than increased duration and intensity of a single sport may be an option
patient education: See “Little League Elbow Syndrome” from Medscape Reference at http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/97101-overview#showall

See “Little League Elbow” from Healthy Children of the American Academy of Pediatrics at https://www.healthychildren.org/English/health-issues/injuries-emergencies/sports-injuries/Pages/Little-League-Elbow.aspx
See “Throwing Injuries in the Elbow in Children” from the American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons at http:// orthoinfo.aaos.org/topic.cfm?topic=A00328 Note

Recent review of the literature has found no updated research evidence on this topic since previous publication on October 14, 2016 Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
